questions.text: Which of the following nerves does not pass through the marked structure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The foramen marked is the Jugular foramen. The Hypoglossal nerve does not pass through the jugular foramen; it passes through the hypoglossal canal. (Option A, B, C Ruled out )

The jugular foramen is a large, irregular opening in the base of the skull, located between the temporal and occipital bones. Several important neurovascular structures pass through it.

Structures passing through the Jugular Foramen

They are commonly divided into three compartments (anterior, middle, and posterior):

Explanation of other options:

Glossopharyngeal nerve (Option A): Cranial Nerve IX passes through the jugular foramen

Vagus nerve (Option B): Cranial Nerve X passes through the jugular foramen

Spinal accessory nerve(Option C): Cranial Nerve XI passes through the jugular foramen.

questions.text: The persistence of which of the following arch arteries is responsible for the congenital anomaly marked in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The above marked defect is suggestive of Patent Ductus Arteriosus, which arises due to persistence of the 6th left pharyngeal arch artery.

Patent Ductus Arteriosus is a congenital heart defect where the ductus arteriosus - a fetal blood vessel that connects the pulmonary artery to the aorta fails to close after birth. Normally closes after birth due to decreased oxygen levels and decreased prostaglandin E2 (PGE2).

Explanation of other options:

6th right pharyngeal arch artery (Option B):

4th left pharyngeal arch artery(Option C):

The 4th left pharyngeal arch artery is crucial in forming the aortic arch, one of the major arteries carrying oxygenated blood from the heart to the body.

4th right pharyngeal arch artery (Option D): The 4th right pharyngeal arch artery is crucial in forming the Proximal part of the right subclavian artery.

questions.text: Upon the delivery of a term newborn, a thorough examination of the umbilical cord reveals crucial information. What are the essential components of a healthy umbilical cord?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A typical umbilical cord of a newborn full-term baby contains two arteries and one vein.

  • 3 veins each draining into the right and left horns of the sinus venosus:
    • Common cardinal vein
    • Umbilical vein
    • Vitelline vein
  • Umbilical veins are coming from the placenta. Later in the fetal circulation, the right umbilical vein regresses, and only the left umbilical vein is left. (Option B, C, and D ruled out)
  • The persisting left umbilical vein in the fetal circulation also degenerates and forms the ligamentum teres of the liver (having no function at all).
  • Vitelline veins drain the yolk sac, which forms the gut tube.
  • The right and left vitelline veins pass through the septum transversum.
  • The septum transversum breaks the vitelline veins into right and left hepatic-cardiac channels.
  • The right hepatic-cardiac channel later contributes to form the terminal part of the IVC, which carries the blood from the liver towards the heart.
  • The right vitelline vein (along with some contribution from the left vitelline vein) forms the portal vein.

questions.text: A woman presented with complaints of loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of the thigh and was diagnosed with meralgia paresthetica. The nerve involved in this condition arises from which of the following nerve roots?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

L2 and L3 (Lateral cutaneous nerve of the Thigh). It is a branch of the lumbar plexus.

The compression of the Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve while passing below the inguinal ligament is known as the meralgia paresthetica. (Option A, B, D Ruled out ). Meralgia paresthetica leads to the loss of sensation in the lateral aspect of the thigh.

  • The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is a purely sensory nerve that arises from L2-L3 of the lumbar plexus.
  • It travels under the inguinal ligament, near the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS), to supply the anterolateral skin of the thigh.
  • Tight belts, obesity, pregnancy, or prolonged hip flexion can compress this nerve, leading to meralgia paresthetica.
    • Causes burning, tingling, or numbness in the distribution area.
  • Motor function remains intact because the nerve is only sensory.

Explanation of other options:

T12 and L1  (Option A): lipohypogastric Nerve innervates the muscle Transversus abdominis and gives cutaneous branches to Anterior cutaneous ramus, Lateral cutaneous ramus.

L1 and L2  (Option B): Genitofemoral Nerve innervates the Cremaster in males

L2, L3, and L4 (Option D): Obturator Nerve innervates the Obturator externus, Adductor longus, Adductor brevis, Gracilis, Pectineus Adductor magnus.

questions.text: The epithelium depicted in the image below is seen in which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given image shows transitional epithelium, which is commonly seen in the ureter.

  • Transitional epithelium is a specialised epithelium lining most of the urinary tract, hence it is also called the urothelium.
  • The deepest layer consists of columnar or cuboidal cells, and the middle layer consists of polyhedral or pear-shaped cells.
  • The surface layer consists of large, polypoid, dome-shaped, or umbrella-shaped As the epithelium gets stretched to accommodate urine, the surface cells become flattened.
  • The cells are called transitional due to this apparent change (transition) from stratified cuboidal epithelium in a relaxed state to stratified squamous epithelium when it is stretched.

They are present in:

  • Collecting ducts
  • Renal pelvis and calyces
  • Ureter
  • Urinary bladder
  • Pre-prostatic and prostatic parts of the urethra

Explanation of other options:

Oesophagus (Option A): It is lined by stratified squamous epithelium. It is multiple layers of cells with flat, scale-like superficial cells providing protection against mechanical stress

Trachea (Option C): It is lined by pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium. It is a single layer of columnar cells with nuclei at different levels, appearing multilayered, lined with cilia, and often containing goblet cells

Duodenum (Option D): The duodenal epithelium is primarily lined by simple columnar epithelium. This type of epithelium is characterised by its single layer of tall, column-shaped cells.

questions.text: A 19-year-old boy presented to the OPD with shoulder pain. He had been training in the gym and had hyperextended his shoulder. On examination, the avulsion of the long head of the triceps was noticed. What is the site at which avulsion of the long head of triceps occurs?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The avulsion of the long head of the triceps occurs at the infraglenoid tubercle of the scapula.

The infraglenoid tubercle is a small bony projection located on the scapula (shoulder blade), just below the glenoid cavity (the socket of the shoulder joint).

Anatomical Details:

  • Bone: Scapula
  • Location: Inferior to the glenoid cavity on the lateral angle of the scapula
  • Function: Serves as the origin point for the long head of the triceps brachii muscle

Muscle Attachment:

  • Muscle: Long head of the triceps brachii
  • Function of Muscle:
    • Extension of the elbow joint
    • Assists in shoulder extension and adduction

Clinical Importance:

  • Avulsion injuries of the long head of the triceps can occur at the infraglenoid tubercle, especially during trauma or hyperextension.
  • Often seen in athletes or due to direct trauma.

Explanation of other options:

Shaft of humerus  (Option A): In strong traction injuries or high-force trauma (e.g., throwing, lifting, or falls), the deltoid can avulse its insertion from the humeral shaft.

Delotoid tuberosity of the humerus(Option B): The avulsion of the deltoid happens at the Delotoid tuberosity of the humerus.The deltoid inserts on the deltoid tuberosity of the humeral shaft (lateral side, roughly mid-shaft)

Supraglenoid tubercle(Option D): The avulsion of the long head of the biceps happens at the supraglenoid tubercle of the scapula.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The pyriform sinus (also called piriform recess or piriform fossa) is a mucosal recess located on either side of the laryngeal inlet in the hypopharynx (the lower part of the pharynx).

Anatomical Location:

  • Lies between:
    • Medially: the laryngeal inlet (opening of the larynx)
    • Laterally: the thyroid cartilage and thyrohyoid membrane
  • It's part of the laryngopharynx, which is posterior to the larynx.

Function:

  • Guides food and liquid around the laryngeal inlet into the oesophagus during swallowing
  • Helps prevent aspiration by channelling material away from the airway

Clinical Relevance:

1. Foreign Body Entrapment:

  • Fish bones, pills, or small objects often lodge here
  • Easily visualised with flexible laryngoscopy or imaging

2. Internal Branch of Superior Laryngeal Nerve:

  • This nerve lies beneath the mucosa of the pyriform sinus
  • Vulnerable to injury during surgery or foreign body removal
  • Damage can lead to loss of sensation above the vocal cords → increased aspiration risk

3. Pyriform Sinus Fistula:

  • A congenital anomaly (from remnants of the 3rd or 4th pharyngeal pouch)
  • It can cause recurrent neck infections in children.

4. Visualization:

  • Seen during laryngoscopy, endoscopy, or barium swallow studies
  • Appears as a pear-shaped depression on either side of the laryngeal inlet

Explanation of other options:

Thyroid cartilage(Option A): The thyroid cartilage is the largest of the laryngeal cartilages. It forms the bulk of the anterior wall of the larynx and gives rise to the visible laryngeal prominence (commonly known as the Adam’s apple).

  • Lies at the level of the C4-C5 vertebrae
  • Situated anterior to the larynx, superior to the cricoid cartilage

Epiglottis(Option B): The epiglottis is a leaf-shaped flap of elastic cartilage that sits at the top of the larynx. Its main role is to protect the airway during swallowing by covering the laryngeal inlet.

Vallecula(Option D): The term vallecula (plural: valleculae) refers to an anatomical depression or groove. It's used in several contexts in the body, but most commonly:

  • Oropharyngeal vallecula: Can collect food or secretions; sometimes examined in swallowing studies.
  • Cerebellar vallecula: Important in brain imaging and neurosurgery as a landmark.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male who is a known case of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus presents with epistaxis, which does not respond to conservative measures and nasal packing. Which of the following arteries should be prioritised for ligation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The sphenopalatine artery is the main blood supply to the posterior nasal cavity. Posterior epistaxis (especially in elderly hypertensive patients) commonly involves this artery. It is often called the "artery of epistaxis."

When packing fails, endoscopic ligation or embolisation of the sphenopalatine artery is the preferred next step.

The following arteries are ligated for control of epistaxis.

  • Transnasal Endoscopic Sphenopalatine Artery Ligation(TESPAL) is done first.
  • If uncontrolled, ligation of the maxillary arteryis done.
  • Then, ligation of the external carotid arteryabove the origin of the superior thyroid artery should be done.
  • If still uncontrolled, ligation of the ethmoidal arteries is done.

Explanation of other options:

Posterior ethmoidal artery  (Option A): supplies the Roof of the nasal cavity, ethmoid sinuses, and has a rare role in epistaxis

Anterior ethmoidal artery(Option B): more involved in anterior/superior epistaxis.

Greater palatine artery (Option D): supplies the inferior nasal septum and palate and has a Minor, accessory role in epistaxis

questions.text: The marked structure does not have which of the following components?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is a dissection of the neck region, where the vagus nerve can be seen descending within the carotid sheath, closely related to the common carotid artery and internal jugular vein. The vagus nerve does not have the GSE (General Somatic Efferent) component.

GSE (General somatic efferent) supplies muscles of the head and neck with somatic origin.

The organisation of cranial nerve nuclei in the brainstem follows a dorsal-to-ventral arrangement of afferents and efferents, with somatic afferent nuclei most dorsal and somatic efferent nuclei most ventral.

  • In the embryological development of the neural tube, particularly in the brainstem, the alar plate (sensory) lies dorsally, and the basal plate (motor) lies ventrally.
  • These give rise to functional columns of cranial nerve nuclei, arranged from dorsal to ventral as follows:
    • Afferent (Sensory) Columns - Dorsally placed:
      • Somatic Afferent (SA) - Somatic sensory (e.g., trigeminal sensory nucleus)
      • Visceral Afferent (VA) - Visceral sensory (e.g., nucleus tractus solitarius)
    • Efferent (Motor) Columns - Ventrally placed:
      • Visceral Efferent (VE) - Autonomic motor (e.g., dorsal motor nucleus of vagus)
      • Somatic Efferent (SE) - Somatic motor (e.g., hypoglossal nucleus)
  • This arrangement is preserved in the floor of the fourth ventricle, particularly in the pons and medulla, and helps localise lesions based on clinical presentation.

choices.text: Nerve to the mylohyoid and the facial nerve
Facial nerve and spinal accessory nerve
Spinal accessory nerve and facial nerve

questions.text: Which pair of nerves supplies the muscles marked A and B, respectively?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The muscles marked as A and B are the anterior and posterior bellies of the digastric, respectively, which are supplied by the nerve to mylohyoid and the facial nerve, respectively

  • The mylohyoid nerve is a branch of the inferior alveolar nerve,
  • The inferior alveolar nerve is a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3), which is the third division of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V) (Option B, C, D ruled out )
  • The posterior belly of the digastric muscle receives a digastric branch from the facial nerve after it exits the stylomastoid foramen
  • This is part of the branchial motor (special visceral efferent) component of CN VII.

questions.text: During eversion of the foot, which of the following ligaments is most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Among the given options, the deltoid ligament, also known as the medial collateral ligament of the ankle, is most likely to be injured during eversion of the foot

Inversion injury:

  • An inversion force with the foot in plantar flexion results in the sprain of the anterior talofibular ligament of the ankle.
  • It is the most common ligament injury occurring in the body.

Eversion injury:

  • Eversion forces on the foot result in the deltoid ligament injuries.
  • On examination, there is tenderness over the medial malleolus.

Explanation of other options:

Anterior talofibular (Option A): The most common Injury occurs during Inversion & plantarflexion

Posterior talofibular (Option C): Injury happens during inversion

Calcaneofibular (Option D): Injury happens during inversion

questions.text: During an abdominal surgery, the surgeon accidentally nicks a structure that passes posterior to the epiploic foramen, which results in profuse bleeding. Which of the following structures is most likely to get injured?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The inferior vena cava lies immediately posterior to the epiploic foramen and is likely to be injured in this case.

Epiploic foramen :

Also known as the Foramen of Winslow/omental foramen, it is a passageway between the greater peritoneal sac and the lesser peritoneal sac.

Boundaries :

  • Superiorly - caudate lobe of the liver
  • Inferiorly - the first part of the duodenum
  • Anteriorly - right free margin of the lesser omentum (hepatoduodenal part)
  • Posteriorly - inferior vena cava

Explanation of other options:

Aorta (Option A): located more posterior and to the left of the midline; not near the epiploic foramen

Hepatic artery(Option B): located anterior to the epiploic foramen within the hepatoduodenal ligament

Portal vein(Option D): Located anterior to the epiploic foramen, within the hepatoduodenal ligament

questions.text: Identify the marked structure that passes inferior to the posterior belly of the digastric and can be seen after submandibular gland resection
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The marked structure points to the hypoglossal nerve, which passes medial to the deep part of the submandibular gland

Anatomical Course of Hypoglossal Nerve:

  • Emerges from the hypoglossal canal in the skull.
  • Passes deep to the posterior belly of the digastric and stylohyoid muscles.
  • Runs deep to the submandibular gland and superficial to the hyoglossus muscle.
  • It travels inferior and lateral to the lingual nerve and medial to the gland's deep part.

Submandibular gland:

questions.text: A patient presents with cancer near the anal opening. Which of the following groups of lymph nodes is most likely to be involved in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cancer near the anal opening is more likely to be below the pectinate line, and therefore, lymph nodes spread first to the superficial inguinal lymph nodes.

Explanation of other options:

Deep inguinal lymph nodes(Option B): Receive drainage from deeper structures, not the superficial perianal skin

Internal iliac lymph nodes (Option C): Drain above the pectinate line

External iliac lymph nodes (Option D): Drain parts of the pelvic organs, but do not drain  the anal skin

choices.text: Anterior grey horn of the spinal cord in the cervical region
Corticospinal tract in the cervical region

questions.text: A patient presents with muscle wasting, reduced tone, and weakness of the right hand. Fine motor movements, such as dough kneading, are also affected. Which of the following structures is most likely to be impaired in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical features and signs presented by the patient strongly suggest lower motor neuron (LMN) involvement, specifically affecting the hand muscles. The anterior (ventral) grey horn of the spinal cord contains the cell bodies of lower motor neurons (LMNs) that innervate skeletal muscles.

In the cervical region, especially segments C8–T1, these LMNs supply the intrinsic muscles of the hand.

Damage here causes:

  • Flaccid paralysis
  • Muscle wasting (atrophy)
  • Fasciculations (sometimes)
  • Loss of fine motor control

Explanation of other options:

Internal capsule (Option B): Would cause upper motor neuron (UMN) signs (spasticity, hyperreflexia) and involve more extensive areas (not isolated hand wasting)

Corticospinal tract in the cervical region(Option C): Causes UMN signs (no wasting), often affects both upper and lower limbs on the same side

Brainstem (Option D): likely affects cranial nerves, not just the hand; more generalised or bilateral signs would be expected in case of brain stem injury.
